crnrstn_element.crnrstn_description:
While the genesis of the CRNRSTN Suite :: lay in the proper configuration of the crnrstn :: class object, the primary interface between the CRNRSTN Suite :: and the application comes into existence with the instantiation of the environmentals :: class object. The crnrstn :: class object consumes all user-specified and $_SERVER predefined environmental configuration parameters for any and all potential environments plus the running environment...respectively, but it is the environmentals :: class object which makes the ultimate determination about which environmental profile or "wall" the CRNRSTN Suite :: needs to join to the application.
As such, the constructor of the environmentals :: class object consumes one parameter...the previously instantiated and properly configured crnrstn :: class object...and then processes all of the configuration information contained therein...selecting the appropriate settings for the present and running environment.
Once the selection is made, the "genetics" of the chosen environmental profile are flashed to session cache (using the appropriate session encryption mechanisms where specified), and ALL the other unused configuration profiles along with the original crnrstn :: class object are immediately destroyed to free up memory.
To be more specific, once the running environment has been detected, the constructor of the environmentals :: class object then parses through the crnstn :: class object (1) cloning what it needs from the crnrstn :: class object and (2) immediately destroying the cloned resource within the crnrstn object. By the time the crnrstn :: class object has been fully traversed, it is nothing but an empty shell, and (3) finally that too is destroyed.
Therefore, upon the successful instantiation of the environmentals :: class object, a streamlined and potentially encrypted packet of configuration data has been stored in memory for the CRNRSTN Suite :: to access for the facilitation of the applications' operation within the running hosting environment.
